awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Travel: Geosciences United - A joint Technical Conference of the National Association of Black Geoscientists and the American Geophysical Union
awd_abstract_narration:
The National Association of Black Geoscientists (NABG) and the American Geophysical Union (AGU) will host a joint student-centered conference. The two organizations will host a technical conference with the theme “Geosciences United: Collaborating for a Sustainable and Equitable Future at the 42nd NABG Annual Technical Conference”. Requested support will defray registration, travel and subsistence expenses of approximately forty student participants. The conference will be held at the AGU headquarters in Washington D.C. on 27-30 September 2023 as a hybrid event (in-person and virtual). The PIs expect that this conference will attract attendees representing many of the federal agencies because of its central location at AGU headquarters in Washington, DC. In addition, the PIs will actively recruit a national cadre of students from minority serving institutions (MSIs) and other institutions who are majoring in geoscience disciplines representing atmospheric sciences, geoscience, marine sciences, and environmental sciences. Students will present research and participate in other activities of the conference. The objective is to expand the disciplinary representation of NABG to include more students from MSIs interested in the broader disciplines of Geosciences and to build new relationships to unite geosciences disciplines.

During the past year, land-falling hurricanes and extreme drought/extreme flooding, and wildfires directly impacted the U.S. Thus, the relevance of atmospheric and environmental sciences to NABG members and their employers presents obvious opportunities to broaden the disciplinary areas of NABG while also engaging a broader audience of scholars and students in these disciplines. This meeting builds on successful efforts to improve the diversity of the geoscience workforce since 2009 and serves as an opportunity for academic institutions, government agencies, and the energy/environmental industry to recruit students from underrepresented groups to STEM disciplines and employment in the national geosciences workforce.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

NABG Annual Technical Conferences: Advancing Geoscience and Inclusion

In 2023, the American Geophysical Union (AGU) received a National Science Foundation (NSF) grant to support the 42nd Annual Technical Conference of the National Association of Black Geoscientists (NABG). Hosted at the AGU Conference Center in Washington, DC, from September 27–30, the event focused on “Geoscience United: Collaborating for a Sustainable and Equitable Future.” Discussions and workshops explored renewable energy, resource management, and cutting-edge geoscience innovations, featuring presentations in climate science, geochemistry, marine science, and more. Strong sponsorship and AGU’s in-kind contributions ensured continued funding for the 2024 conference.

The 43rd NABG Annual Technical Conference, themed “Diverse Perspectives, Unified Solutions: Bridging Communities through Geoscience,” took place September 4–7, 2024, at Georgia State University in collaboration with its Department of Geosciences and CSAW Learning Ecosystem. With over 200 attendees, including 107 students, 76% graduate and 24% undergraduate, the conference set a new attendance record, reinforcing its impact on geoscience education and professional development.

Intellectual Merit

The 2024 event showcased a growing body of geoscientific research, featuring 95 abstracts across poster sessions, oral presentations, and lightning talks. NABG awarded top student presentations to support their academic growth. Additionally, 18 exhibitors, including universities, industry leaders, and professional societies, engaged with attendees to provide networking and career opportunities.

Keynote speeches and panel discussions tackled pressing geoscience challenges, including:

  • Diversity in Geosciences – Addressing systemic barriers and pathways for inclusion.
  • Community Advocacy and Environmental Justice – Insights from the CSAW Learning Ecosystem.
  • Data Science in Geosciences – Best practices in data security and collaboration.
  • Science Communication – Effective strategies for making scientific research accessible.
  • USGS Insights – Director Dave Applegate’s perspective on environmental and resource challenges.

Broader Impacts

The NABG conferences have significantly advanced diversity and inclusion in geosciences through:

  1. Student Support: In 2024, ten students received $10,000 in scholarships, strengthening their academic and research journeys.
  2. Workshops & Training (2023-24):
    • A workshop for international students on U.S. permanent residency pathways.
    • A high school leadership event, supported by Shell, introducing 30 students to geoscience careers.
    • ExxonMobil’s session on low-carbon energy innovations.
  3. Exhibitor Expansion: Five new exhibitors joined longstanding partners, creating new internships and job opportunities.
  4. Community Impact: Field trips, including collaborations with the USGS, EPA, and Georgia State University’s CSAW program, connected attendees with real-world environmental justice initiatives.

Conclusion

The 42nd and 43rd NABG conferences successfully merged scientific advancement with inclusivity, fostering meaningful collaborations and expanding opportunities for underrepresented communities in STEM. By amplifying diverse perspectives and strengthening geoscience networks, these events align with NSF’s mission to enhance diversity, innovation, and public engagement in science.
